description:
From Middle English combren, borrowed from the second element of Old French encombrer, ultimately from Proto-Celtic *kombereti (“to bring together”).
Cognate with German kümmern (“to take care of”).

verbs.description: cumber (third-person singular simple present cumbers, present participle cumbering, simple past and past participle cumbered)

entries.meaning: (transitive, dated) To slow down; to hinder; to burden; to encumber.
examples: Why asks he what avails him not in fight, / And would but cumber and retard his flight?
